content: The Act may be cited as the "10,000 Trained by 2011 Act" and includes findings. The National Science Foundation is recognized for its role in strengthening the nation's information infrastructure and supporting research for automation and digitization in various industries. Basic research, demonstrations, and curriculum development assistance from the NSF are crucial for industry knowledge and workforce readiness. Information management is crucial for industry readiness in utilizing advanced technology. There is a projected 49 percent growth in sectors related to biology by 2010. Currently, there is no systematic plan in place for designing and implementing information systems to help the workforce transition to the information age. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines key terms such as "Director" as the Director of the National Science Foundation, "information" as data in sectors transitioning to digital use, and "institution of higher education" as defined in the Higher Education Act of 1965. The Director, with input from other agencies, awards grants for research on improving information systems in areas like information studies, population informatics, translational informatics, and data security. Grants are merit-reviewed and competitive. The Director awards grants for informatics research centers on a competitive basis, with authorized appropriations for fiscal years 2008 to 2011. The Director awards multiyear grants to institutions of higher education to establish Centers for Informatics Research in consultation with other Federal agencies. Grants are awarded on a competitive basis through merit review. The Centers for Informatics Research are established through multiyear grants awarded to nonprofit institutions based on merit review and competition. The purpose is to conduct innovative, multidisciplinary research in information areas specified in the application process. The application to establish a Center for Informatics Research must be submitted to the Director with required information, including research project descriptions and promoting collaboration among professionals from various disciplines. The Center for Informatics Research aims to bring together professionals from various disciplines, such as information technology specialists, scientists, administrators, and social science researchers. The Director will evaluate applications based on the ability to generate innovative approaches to information. The Center for Informatics Research evaluates applications based on the applicant's ability to generate innovative approaches to information, conduct research in the information field, foster collaborations, support students pursuing information research, and partner with others. The National Science Foundation authorizes appropriations for Centers to foster collaboration and communication among participants. Authorization of appropriations for the National Science Foundation for fiscal years 2008 to 2011: $4,500,000 for 2008, $4,600,000 for 2009, $4,700,000 for 2010, and $4,800,000 for 2011. SEC. 5. NATIONAL SCIENCE FOUNDATION INFORMATION PROGRAMS. Capacity Building Grants program will award grants to institutions of higher education to establish or improve undergraduate and master's degree information programs, increase student enrollment in information fields, provide students with industry experience, and utilize distance learning where possible. The Capacity Building Grants program awards grants to institutions of higher education to enhance information education through distance learning, certification, and degree programs, with a focus on increasing student enrollment and industry experience. Grants are awarded based on merit and competition. The Capacity Building Grants program aims to enhance information education through certification and degree programs, focusing on increasing student enrollment and industry experience. Activities include developing curriculum, establishing programs, creating research opportunities, and acquiring necessary equipment for student instruction. The Capacity Building Grants program aims to enhance information education by acquiring equipment for student instruction, providing faculty opportunities for collaboration, and working with other academic institutions to enhance programs. The Capacity Building Grants program aims to enhance information education by collaborating with academic institutions, establishing student internships, enhancing bridge programs, and other activities as determined by the Director in consultation with other Federal agencies. The Capacity Building Grants program aims to enhance information education through collaborations with academic institutions, student internships, bridge programs, and other activities determined by the Director in consultation with other Federal agencies. Universities and institutions of higher education seeking funding must submit an application with specified requirements. The application for Capacity Building Grants must include a description of the applicant's research and instructional capacity, as well as a plan for building capacity within the institution or consortium. The application for Capacity Building Grants must include a plan to build instructional capacity in information fields, collaborations with relevant agencies or industries, and a study of enrollment and placement data. The application for Capacity Building Grants must include a plan to evaluate the success of the proposed program, including postgraduate assessment of graduate school and job placement. The Director will ensure grants are awarded in various geographic areas and institutions of higher education. An evaluation of the program will be conducted within 3 years of its establishment. The Director will evaluate the grants' impact on increasing students pursuing degrees in information fields. Authorization of appropriations is set for fiscal years 2008-2010. The Director will provide grants under the Scientific and Advanced Technology Act of 1992 to improve education in information fields. Authorization of appropriations is set for fiscal years 2008-2011. The Director will provide grants to improve education in information fields, with authorized appropriations set for fiscal years 2008-2011 totaling $7,000,000 for 2008, $7,200,000 for 2009, $7,400,000 for 2010, and $7,600,000 for 2011. SEC. 6. REPORT ON STANDARDIZATION OF MEASURES RELATED TO DIGITAL INFORMATION. The Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology will report to congressional committees on informatics efforts, standards harmonization, research, and support for executive orders on digitization. The report will include timetables for information standards promulgation and major challenges. The report will include timetables for information standards promulgation, major challenges in reaching these standards, efforts to ensure digital information usability, and actions NIST could take for robust and timely standards.
